Description: Dave Schwartzberg gives an update on mobile security. How real are threats from phones and tablets? What works for BYOD management?

Description: AWS (Amazon Web Services) S3 (Simple Storage Services) supports AES (Advanced Encryption Standard) and other TLAs. This gives us a great example of a setting up controls to ensure controls are set. He

Author: David Giard
Description: An overview of Responder and HoneyCreds, as demonstrated by Ben0xA in his Converge Detroit keynote.

Author: David Giard
Description: Dave Schwartzberg hops in the car with me to describe getting kids involved with hacking, robotics, and coding. He's running Hak4Kidz at conferences across the globe, including BSidesDetroit.

Author: David Giard
Description: Yesterday at Converge, Joel Cardella presented "Welcome to The World of Yesterday, Tomorrow!" The topic was what we can learn from the Challenger disaster. Here's my take on flight rate and

Author: David Giard
Description: Edgy. Our security environments are edgy. And at that edge, we need to see what's coming and going. Ans that's where encryption is both good and bad for security.

Author: David Giard
Description: If you're developing collaboration software, watch your approval workflow. And if you're running Medium, patch your software.

Author: David Giard
Description: Using shard to detect shared passwords, and how it might be used in an employee security awareness program. More here: https://github.com/philwantsfish/shard

Author: David Giard
Description: Today, balloon tower defense-in-depth style, we cover the attack path for ransomware. Eight controls are detailed, each one with a varying degree of effectiveness, that can keep your organization from

VideoTitle: Stolen Phone, Broken Crypto   . J Wolfgang Goerlich       J Wolfgang Goerlich
Author: David Giard
Description: Tennessee says we no longer get a pass on stolen encrypted devices. And Android phones with Qualcomm ARM processors have a new attack vector for stealing encryption keys and brute forcing de-encryptio

Author: David Giard
Description: 98 tasks for security on the wall. 98 security tasks. Instead of taking one down and passing it around, how about finding a better way? Say, by bundling it with active and planned projects?

VideoTitle: Why Model and Detect Late Stage Attacks
Author: David Giard
Description: Think of an attack path (or kill chain) as one of those kids toys where you rotate animals. Heads, bodies, tails. Intrusions, compromises, exfiltrations. Which part is easiest to detect and why?

VideoTitle: Drive Encryption, Secure Wipes, and Awareness
Author: David Giard
Description: A new study finds 78% of used computers have personal and corporate data from their previous owners. Time to check your endpoint data controls. Time, too, to share the story with your employees so the

Author: David Giard
Description: Nobody likes an IT cowboy. Nobody. Then again, everybody needs a hero sometime. Somebody quick on the trigger. Somebody who knows what's what. So I ask, who's your cowboy?

Author: David Giard
Description: Recent attacks on GoToMyPC and Team Viewer shine a spotlight on remote access risks. If someone were compromised by these, would we know? And what subsequent controls would protect our sensitive data?

Author: David Giard
Description: The new version of the Social Engineering Toolkit (SET) can deliver malicious payloads with the Windows HTML Application (HTA) files. Let's talk defense.

Author: David Giard
Description: 154 million voter records were recently exposed. The records included names, addresses, Facebook profiles, gun ownership, and so on. And this highlights the need to check configurations as part of vul

Author: David Giard
Description: Involve people in the creation of security procedures and controls to trigger the IKEA Effect and get buy-in.

Author: David Giard
Description: You know your FICO credit score? Yeah. Now apply that to cyber security. That's what QuadMetrics has developed for FICO. It's coming to a cyber insurance policy near you. Is your organization ready?

Author: David Giard
Description: Rebecca Marquis tweeted out that she was doing housework while listening to these videos. And that made me think. IT security is a lot like cleaning. For example, it works better with a dedicated team

Author: David Giard
Description: Everybody's passwords have been stolen. Now criminals are reusing passwords on other sites. Github responds. LinkedIn responds. Could we?

Author: David Giard
Description: I miss the good old days, when ransomware was left to the professionals and only encrypted data files. Not like BadBlock and these newer round of malware. Those were simpler times.

Author: David Giard
Description: Someone called the help desk with a phish? Laugh at them for falling for it. Some firm got breached? Post it to Facebook and enjoy the schadenfreude. That's often how the IT security community and ind

VideoTitle: Stopping Work that looks like Work
Author: David Giard
Description: When work looks like work, work gets done. Good news for the IT security team. But what if the work is criminal? Today, a story from 0ddJ0bb on how fraudsters used the principle to steal bitcoin.

Author: David Giard
Description: Rapid7 scans the Internet and find millions of unencrypted services. Telnet, databases, printers, and file shares. Welcome to the 1990's internet, today.

Author: David Giard
Description: We encrypted the Web traffic. And then decrypted it across the firewalls. We encrypted the files. And then decrypted them to load databases. We encrypted the disks. Wait. But we decrypted on boot. And

Author: David Giard
Description: A new version of Angler, used for ransomware, is taking advantage of Flash and Silverlight to bypass EMET's memory protection. So should we abandon EMET altogether or what?

Author: David Giard
Description: Setting up rights management and loss prevention for secure file exchange. Hardening the circadian rhythms of our organizations.

Author: David Giard
Description: Thoughts on the "Penetration Tests and Red Team Exercises", the "Application Software Security", and the "Email and Web Browser Protections" controls in the CIS Critical

Author: David Giard
Description: The human readable / machine enforceable theory for IT security policies.

Author: David Giard
Description: To everything, a season. To every security control, an amount of time. To every security architecture, a set lifespan. Assessing and planning for these cycles, today while stuck in traffic.

Author: David Giard
Description: Gesture authentication, the "Robotic Robbery in the Touch Screen" paper, and the cool hand gesture lady. Nothing is safe.

Author: David Giard
Description: Lessons from the TSA we can avoid. Lessons from the cloud aaS we can adopt. And an idea for how to make security a product consumers want.

Author: David Giard
Description: Quick primer on Local File Inclusion (LFI) vulnerabilities in Web apps.

VideoTitle: Career Jumps and the Red Baron
Author: David Giard
Description: A hundred years ago, the Red Baron ruled the skies. A few years before that, however, he was a simple cavalryman. So what lessons can we learn about going from the help desk to the SOC from a guy who

Author: David Giard
Description: Image Magic is vulnerable. Don't just patch. This is an opportunity to evaluate all the controls on the attack path. Done right, we will have 0-day protection.

VideoTitle: Safe Cracking and Time Based Security
Author: David Giard
Description: At a keynote, I pulled out a safe cracker and demonstrated brute forcing. Safes are excellent metaphors for security controls. Take, for example, the TL rating for a given intensity of an attack and a

VideoTitle: OK Cupid and the Broken Heart
Author: David Giard
Description: What can we learn from OK Cupid being scrapped and its users' information being released? Well, for one, we can make sure our Web sites do not get scrapped.

Author: David Giard
Description: There are our business processes. There are our work flows. And then there are third party apps, facilities, and cloud hosting. So how do you do a risk and controls assessment?

VideoTitle: Save a Life or Stop a Virus
Author: David Giard
Description: One time, during heart surgery, the Merge Hemo app locked up. Why? Because of an anti-virus scan. It's an example of what happens when we focus solely on securing technology.

Author: David Giard
Description: Applying the "Swiss Cheese Model" to after action reports to beat the odds with incident response.

Author: David Giard
Description: A four step process for creating a defensible security architecture.

Author: David Giard
Description: Red Team tools exist for PowerShell. Older ones, like PoshSec and PowerSploit, and newer ones like PowerShell Empire. Meantime, criminals weaponized PowerShell scripts with malware like PowerSniff and

VideoTitle: Locky and Having a fighting chance
Author: David Giard
Description: Someone infiltrated the Locky network and disabled the ransomeware. We've seen this happen before. Turns out, the criminals make as many mistakes as we do. And this means we have a fighting chance.

Author: David Giard
Description: If data is the life blood of the organization, then data exchange is the steady heartbeat. Data in, data out (beat). Data in, data out (beat). And encryption protects that flow.

Author: David Giard
Description: PDCA, Plan-Do-Check-Act, is all fine and good. The trouble is delaying feedback. So here's some ways to get implementation and assessment teams closer to tighten the feedback loop.

Author: David Giard
Description: Content management systems are an oft used system for criminals. A toy manufacturer provides a recent example, as their unpatched Joomla system was hijacked to distribute ransomeware with Angler.

Author: David Giard
Description: After last week's video on phishing response metrics, a question came in. How does IT respond and clean up phishing emails?

Author: David Giard
Description: If the end result is the response to an attack, why don't more metrics measure the response? Take phishing. We need to track the time it takes for IT to investigate and blackhole a phish. That's what

Author: David Giard
Description: Flexibility gives the defense an advantage. Reusable and repurposable systems, particularly for disaster recovery, are a good place to begin building that flexibility. Also, seriously, twelve people i

Author: David Giard
Description: Start small. Start some where. Start iterating and improving. From frameworks like ISO 27001 to maturity models like BSIMM, we can make a minimum version which reduces risk with a reasonable amount of

Author: David Giard
Description: A million downloads can't be wrong. Except, of course, when the mobile apps access excessive amounts of personal data. Oh, and, except when the data is transmitted in clear text. Leave it to the presi
